Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer violated Lam's rights by denying the application without a personal interview or exercising discretion under s. 11(3)
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 11(3)
Evidence_Assessment: Application lacked evidence of chef-cook training; assessed as assistant manager where no labor demand existed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility and procedural fairness breach
Legal_Rule: Visa officers must act in good faith but are not obligated to conduct interviews for ambiguous applications; discretion under s. 11(3) may be exercised if reasons are submitted
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of personal interview and failure to exercise discretion
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of procedural fairness and statutory discretion not exercised
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No obligation to conduct interview; no duty to inquire further
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of documentation proving chef-cook training
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, judicial review principles
Applicant_Challenge: Denial of permanent residence application without interview or discretionary consideration
Legal_Rule_Source: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 11(3)
Defendant_Response: Application incomplete; qualifications unverified; no labor market demand for assistant manager
Decision_Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review setting aside decision or certifying question for appeal
Legal_Provision: s. 11(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient evidence of qualifications for claimed occupation
Governing_Rule: Visa officers have discretion under s. 11(3) when reasons are provided; no mandatory interview requirement
